title: First presidency of Donald Trump
added: In September 2020, Brian Murphy — who until August 2020 was the [[Under Secretary of Homeland Security for Intelligence and Analysis]], asserted in a whistleblower complaint that during the shutdown senior [[DHS]] officials sought to inflate the number of known or suspected terrorists who had been apprehended at the border, in an effort to increase support for funding the wall. ''NBC News'' reported that at the time a DHS spokeswoman, [[Katie Waldman]], pushed the network to retract a story that correctly cited only six such apprehensions in the first half of 2018, compared to the nearly 4,000 a year the administration was publicly claiming. The story was not retracted, and Waldman later became the press secretary for vice president [[Mike Pence]] and husband of Trump advisor [[Stephen Miller (political advisor)|Stephen Miller]].<ref>https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/immigration/dhs-spokeswoman-pushed-nbc-news-retract-accurate-story-about-terrorists-n1239702</ref><ref>https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/national-security/whistleblower-says-top-dhs-officials-distorted-intel-match-trump-statements-n1239685</ref>

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
added: In September 2020, Brian Murphy — who until August 2020 was the [[Under Secretary of Homeland Security for Intelligence and Analysis]], asserted in a whistleblower complaint<ref>{{cite paper|last=Murphy|first=Brian|date=September 8, 2020|url=https://intelligence.house.gov/uploadedfiles/murphy_wb_dhs_oig_complaint9.8.20.pdf|title=In the Matter of Murphy, Brian Principal Deputy Under Secretary Department of Homeland Security Office of Intelligence & Analysis Complaint||journal=-|publisher=United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|accessdate=September 10, 2020}}</ref>that during the shutdown senior [[DHS]] officials sought to inflate the number of known or suspected terrorists who had been apprehended at the border, in an effort to increase support for funding the wall. ''NBC News'' reported that at the time a DHS spokeswoman, [[Katie Waldman]], pushed the network to retract a story that correctly cited only six such apprehensions in the first half of 2018, compared to the nearly 4,000 a year the administration was publicly claiming. The story was not retracted, and Waldman later became the press secretary for vice president [[Mike Pence]] and husband of Trump advisor [[Stephen Miller (political advisor)|Stephen Miller]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/immigration/dhs-spokeswoman-pushed-nbc-news-retract-accurate-story-about-terrorists-n1239702|title=DHS official pushed NBC News to retract story on terrorists at border|website=NBC News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/national-security/whistleblower-says-top-dhs-officials-distorted-intel-match-trump-statements-n1239685|title=Whistleblower: DHS officials distorted intelligence to match Trump rhetoric|website=NBC News}}</ref>

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
added: In September 2020, Brian Murphy — who until August 2020 was the [[Under Secretary of Homeland Security for Intelligence and Analysis]]—asserted in a whistleblower complaint<ref>{{cite paper|last=Murphy|first=Brian|date=September 8, 2020|url=https://intelligence.house.gov/uploadedfiles/murphy_wb_dhs_oig_complaint9.8.20.pdf|title=In the Matter of Murphy, Brian Principal Deputy Under Secretary Department of Homeland Security Office of Intelligence & Analysis Complaint||journal=-|publisher=United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|accessdate=September 10, 2020}}</ref> that during the shutdown senior [[DHS]] officials sought to inflate the number of known or suspected terrorists who had been apprehended at the border, in an effort to increase support for funding the wall. ''NBC News'' reported that at the time a DHS spokeswoman, [[Katie Waldman]], pushed the network to retract a story that correctly cited only six such apprehensions in the first half of 2018, compared to the nearly 4,000 a year the administration was publicly claiming. The story was not retracted, and Waldman later became the press secretary for vice president [[Mike Pence]] and husband of Trump advisor [[Stephen Miller (political advisor)|Stephen Miller]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/immigration/dhs-spokeswoman-pushed-nbc-news-retract-accurate-story-about-terrorists-n1239702|title=DHS official pushed NBC News to retract story on terrorists at border|website=NBC News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/national-security/whistleblower-says-top-dhs-officials-distorted-intel-match-trump-statements-n1239685|title=Whistleblower: DHS officials distorted intelligence to match Trump rhetoric|website=NBC News}}</ref>

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
added: President Trump would later announce on October 2, via [[Twitter]] that both he and [[First Lady Melania Trump|Melania Trump]] tested positive for [[COVID-19]], and would begin quarantining at the White House. This came after an advisor to the president, [[Hope Hicks]], also tested positive for the virus herself, with that announcement coming just two hours before the President himself was confirmed to have COVID-19.

title: First presidency of Donald Trump
